source: Mora, C., Myers, R.A., Coll, M., Libralato, S., Pitcher, T.J., Sumaila, R.U., Worm, B. (2009). Management Effectiveness of the World's Marine Fisheries. PLoS Biol, 7(6), e1000131. [doi:10.1371/journal.pbio.1000131](http://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1000131)

extra: The per capita purchasing power parity (PPP) adjusted gross domestic product (GDP): GDPpcPPP.

component_name: Coastal human population as a proxy for trend in trash
source: CIESIN & CIAT (Center for International Earth Science Information Network / Columbia University, & Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical) (2005). Gridded Population of the World, Version 3 (GPWv3): Population Density Grid, Future Estimates. Palisades, NY. [NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC)](http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/gpw-v3-population-density-future-estimates)
extra: Coastal population, defined as the total population inland of 25 miles, extracted from Gridded Population of the World (GPW) Population Density Grid Future Estimates.

component_name: Trends in fertilizer pollution as a proxy for nutrient pollution
source: FAO's statistical database FAOSTAT (http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/browse/R/*/E)Halpern, B. S. et al. (2015). Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. Nature Communications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled data based on fertilizer consumption from the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO; Halpern et al. 2015).

component_name: Trends in access to improved sanitation as a proxy for pathogen pollution trend
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund's Joint Monitoring Programme (WHO/UNICEF's JMP)(http://www.wssinfo.org/data-estimates/table)
extra: Trends in percent of population without access to improved sanitation facilities.

source: FAO's statistical database, FAOSTAT (http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/browse/R/*/E)Halpern, B. S. et al. (2015). Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. Nature Communications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled chemical pollution from commercial shipping traffic, ports and harbors, and pesticide use (Halpern et al. 2015).

component_name: B/Bmsy estimates obtained using the catch-MSY method
source: Martell, S., & Froese, R. (2013). A simple method for estimating MSY from catch and resilience. Fish and Fisheries 14(4): 504-514. [doi:10.1111/j.1467-2979.2012.00485.x](https://dx/doi/org/10.1111/j.1467-2979.2012.00485.x)
extra: The ratio of fish population abundance compared to the abundance required to deliver maximum sustainable yield, obtained from the catch-MSY model (Martell & Froese, 2013).

component_name: Catch data for each Taxon/FAO/SAU region averaged across years
source: Sea Around Us Project (SAUP) (http://www.seaaroundus.org)

source: United Nations - World Conservation Monitoring Centre's World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) through [Protected Planet](http://www.protectedplanet.net).

source: CIESIN & CIAT (Center for International Earth Science Information Network / Columbia University & Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical) (2005). Gridded Population of the World, Version 3 (GPWv3): Population Density Grid, Future Estimates. Palisades, NY. NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC) (http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/gpw-v3-population-density-future-estimates).

source: FAO global aquaculture production (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-aquaculture-production/en).

source: FAO global aquaculture production (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-aquaculture-production/en).

source: Trujillo P. (2008). Using a mariculture sustainability index to rank countries' performances. In: A comparative assessment of biodiversity, fisheries and aquaculture in 53 countries' Exclusive Economic Zones, Alder J, Pauly D, editors. Fisheries Centre Research Report, vol. 16(7) p. 28-56.

source: Reefs at Risk Revisited (http://www.wri.org/publication/reefs-at-risk-revisited).

source: Reefs at Risk Revisited (http://www.wri.org/publication/reefs-at-risk-revisited).
extra: Destructive artisanal poison (cyanide) fishing (Reefs at Risk Revisited).

component_name: Product peak harvest divided by sum of all product peak harvest values, per region
source: FAO fisheries statistics (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-commodities-production/en).
extra: Ratio of harvest of of six marine products (coral, fish oil, seaweed and plants, shells, sponges, ornamental fish) from FAO.

component_name: Harvest yield of marine natural products, smoothed
source: FAO fisheries statistics (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-commodities-production/en).
extra: Yield in metric tonnes of six marine products (coral, fish oil, seaweed and plants, shells, sponges, ornamental fish) from FAO.

component_name: Harvest ratio to peak yield of marine natural products
source: FAO fisheries statistics (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-commodities-production/en).
extra: Ratio to max yield (tonnes) of product peak for six marine products (coral, fish oil, seaweed and plants, shells, sponges, ornamental fish) from FAO.

source: Feely, R., Doney, S. & Cooley, S. (2009) Ocean acidification: present conditions and future changes in a high-CO2 world.Oceanography 22:36-47. (doi:10.5670/oceanog.2009.95).J. Afflerbach et al. (2015). (https://github.com/OHI-Science/ohiprep/tree/master/globalprep/Pressures_OceanAcidification/v2015)
extra: Change in current year's modeled aragonite saturation state (Feely et al. 2010) relative to historical mean (1880-1889).

source: Nicholls R. J. and Cazenave A. (2010). Sea-level rise and its impact on coastal zones. Science 328: 1517-1520  [doi:10.1126/science.1185782](http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1185782). AVISO Satellite Altimetry Data (http://www.aviso.oceanobs.com/en/news/ocean-indicators/mean-sea-level/processing-corrections.html).J. Afflerbach et al. (2015). (https://github.com/OHI-Science/ohiprep/tree/master/globalprep/Pressures_SeaLevelRise/v2015)
extra: Modeled sea level rise (Nicholls and Cazenave 2010).

source: AVHRR Pathfinder Version 5.0 SST data (http://pathfinder.nodc.noaa.gov)Casey, K. S., Brandon, T. B., Cornillon, P., and Evans, R. (2010). The past, present and future of the AVHRR Pathfinder SST Program, Oceanography from Space: Revisited, eds. V. Barale, J.F.R. Gower, and L. Alberotanza, Springer [doi:10.1007/978-90-481-8681-5_16](http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-90-481-8681-5_16).J. Afflerbach et al. (2015). (https://github.com/OHI-Science/ohiprep/tree/master/globalprep/Pressures_SST)
extra: Sea surface temperature based on temperature anomolies provided by GHRSST and the US National Oceanographic Data Center.

source: Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC) (http://disc.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/data-holdings/PIP/erythemal_uv_irradiance.shtml)J. Afflerbach et al. (2015). (https://github.com/OHI-Science/ohiprep/tree/master/globalprep/Pressures_UV)

component_name: High bycatch caused by artisanal fishing
source: Reefs at Risk Revisited (http://www.wri.org/publication/reefs-at-risk-revisited)
extra: The presence of destructive artisanal blast and poison (cyanide) fishing (Reefs at Risk Revisited).

component_name: Low bycatch caused by artisanal fishing
source: Halpern, B. S., Walbridge S., Selkoe, K. A., Kappel, C. V., Micheli, F., D'Agrosa, C., Bruno, J. F., Casey, K. S., Ebert, C., Fox, H. E., Fujita, R., Heinemann, D., Lenihan, H. S., Madin, E. M. P., Perry, M. T., Selig, E. R., Spalding, M., Steneck, R., Watson, R. (2008) A global map of human impact on marine ecosystems. Science, 3199(5865): 948-952 [doi:10.1126/science.1149345](http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1149345).FAO fisheries statistics (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-capture-production/en)
extra: Modeled low bycatch artisanal fishing using non-destructive practices (Halpern et al. 2008) based on FAO fisheries statistics.

component_name: High bycatch caused by commercial fishing
source: Halpern, B. S., Walbridge S., Selkoe, K. A., Kappel, C. V., Micheli, F., D'Agrosa, C., Bruno, J. F., Casey, K. S., Ebert, C., Fox, H. E., Fujita, R., Heinemann, D., Lenihan, H. S., Madin, E. M. P., Perry, M. T., Selig, E. R., Spalding, M., Steneck, R., Watson, R. (2008) A global map of human impact on marine ecosystems. Science, 3199(5865): 948-952 [doi:10.1126/science.1149345](http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1149345).
extra: Modeled destructive commercial fishing practices by 5 different gear types (Halpern et al. 2008).

component_name: Low bycatch caused by commercial fishing
source: Halpern, B. S., Walbridge S., Selkoe, K. A., Kappel, C. V., Micheli, F., D'Agrosa, C., Bruno, J. F., Casey, K. S., Ebert, C., Fox, H. E., Fujita, R., Heinemann, D., Lenihan, H. S., Madin, E. M. P., Perry, M. T., Selig, E. R., Spalding, M., Steneck, R., Watson, R. (2008) A global map of human impact on marine ecosystems. Science, 3199(5865): 948-952 [doi:10.1126/science.1149345](http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1149345).
extra: Modeled least destructive commercial fishing practices by 2 different gear types (Halpern et al. 2008).

component_name: Targeted harvest of cetaceans and sea turtles
source: FAO fisheries statistics (http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-capture-production/en)
extra: Targeted harvest of cetaceans and marine turtles, from FAO fisheries data.

component_name: Coastal population density as a proxy for intertidal habitat destruction
source: CIESIN & CIAT (Center for International Earth Science Information Network /Columbia University & Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical) (2005). Gridded Population of the World, Version 3 (GPWv3): Population Density Grid, Future Estimates. Palisades, NY. NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC) (http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/gpw-v3-population-density-future-estimates).Halpern, B. S., Walbridge S., Selkoe, K. A., Kappel, C. V., Micheli, F., D'Agrosa, C., Bruno, J. F., Casey, K. S., Ebert, C., Fox, H. E., Fujita, R., Heinemann, D., Lenihan, H. S., Madin, E. M. P., Perry, M. T., Selig, E. R., Spalding, M., Steneck, R., Watson, R. (2008) A global map of human impact on marine ecosystems. Science, 3199(5865): 948-952 [doi:10.1126/science.1149345](http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1149345).
extra: Coastal population, defined as the total population inland of 10 miles, extracted from Gridded Population of the World (GPW) Population Density Grid Future Estimates.

component_name: High bycatch artisanal fishing practices as a proxy for subtidal hard bottom habitat destruction
source: Reefs at Risk Revisited (http://www.wri.org/publication/reefs-at-risk-revisited)
extra: The presence of destructive artisanal blast fishing (Reefs at Risk Revisited).

component_name: Demersal destructive commercial fishing practices relative to soft-bottom habitat area as a proxy for soft bottom habitat destruction
source: Sea Around Us Project, SAUP (http://www.seaaroundus.org/)
extra: Spatially distributed commercial catch data by fishing gear type, developed by Sea Around Us Project and habitat data.

source: Halpern, B. S., Longo, C., Hardy, D., et al. (2012). An index to assess the health and benefits of the global ocean. Nature (doi:10.1038/nature11397).

source: FAO's statistical database FAOSTAT (http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/browse/R/*/E).Halpern, B. S. et al. (2015). Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. NatureCommunications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled chemical pollution from commercial shipping traffic, ports and harbors, and pesticide use (Halpern et al. 2015).

component_name: Coastal chemical pollution within 3 nm offshore
source: FAO's statistical database FAOSTAT (http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/browse/R/*/E).Halpern, B. S. et al. (2015). Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. Nature Communications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled chemical pollution from commercial shipping traffic, ports and harbors, and pesticide use (Halpern et al. 2015), primarily land-based chemical pollution due to 3nm offshore buffer.

component_name: Fertilizer pollution as a proxy for nutrient pollution

Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. NatureCommunications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled data based on fertilizer consumption from the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO, Halpern et al. 2015).

component_name: Coastal fertilizer pollution as a proxy for nutrient pollution within 3nm offshore
source: FAO's statistical database FAOSTAT (http://faostat3.fao.org/faostat-gateway/go/to/browse/R/*/E).Halpern, B. S. et al. (2015). Spatial and temporal changes in cumulative human impacts on the world's ocean. NatureCommunications 6(7615). [doi: 10.1038/ncomms8615](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8615/full/ncomms8615.html)
extra: Modeled data based on fertilizer consumption from the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO, Halpern et al. 2015).
